Opening|The Nightmare Before Christmas b.artistInfo: The Nightmare Before Christmas by Patrick Stewart
Opening|The Nightmare Before Christmas b.lyrics: [NARRATOR]T'was a long time ago, longer now than it seemsIn a place that perhaps you've seen in your dreamsFor the story that you are about to be toldBegan with the holiday worlds of oldNow you've probably wondered where holidays come fromIf you haven't, I'd say it's time you begunFor the holidays are the result of much fussAnd hard work for the worlds that create them for usWell, you see now, quite simply that's all that they doMaking one unique holiday especially for youBut once a calamity ever so greatOccurred when two holidays met by mistake
Opening|The Nightmare Before Christmas b.fact: “Opening” is a monologue spoken by Patrick Stewart for the movie “The Nightmare Before Christmas.” This monologue is meant to tell the audience the world we are getting into.

This Is Halloween|by The\u00a0Citizens O.fact: “This is Halloween” is the song to introduce the start to the movie “The Nightmare before Christmas.” Directed by Henry Selick, who worked on other movies such as Coraline, James and the Giant Peach, and Monkeybone.  As the starting scene takes place, the town called “Halloween” is being introduced through lyrics sung by various characters, who are residents of the Halloween Town.

Jack's Lament.title: Jack's Lament
Jack's Lament.lyrics: [JACK]There are few who deny at what I do I am the bestFor my talents are renowned far and wideWhen it comes to surprises in the moonlit nightI excel without ever even tryingWith the slightest little effort of my ghost-like charmsI have seen grown men give out a shriekWith the wave of my hand and a well-placed moanI have swept the very bravest off their feetYet year after year, it's the same routineAnd I grow so weary of the sound of screamsAnd I, Jack, the Pumpkin KingHave grown so tired of the same old thingOh, somewhere deep inside of these bonesAn emptiness began to growThere's something out there far from my homeA longing that I've never knownI'm a master of fright and a demon of lightAnd I'll scare you right out of your pantsTo a guy in Kentucky, I'm Mister UnluckyAnd I'm known throughout England and FranceAnd since I am dead I can take off my headTo recite Shakespearean quotationsNo animal nor man can scream like I canWith the fury of my recitationsBut who here would ever understandThat the Pumpkin King with the skeleton grinWould tire of his crown? If they only understoodHe would give it all up if he only couldOh, there's an empty place in my bonesThat calls out for something unknownThe fame and praise come year after yearDoes nothing for these empty tears
Jack's Lament.fact: This is the “I want” song of The Nightmare Before Christmas. Jack tired having the same thing every year and nothing else, even though he plays a big role in the celebration.

What's This?.fact: Just as Dorothy left her seemingly-dull home in Kansas and travelled to the colorful world of Oz, Jack has travelled from gloomy Halloween Town into Christmas Town, where things are brighter and more joyful than he has ever known.

Town Meeting Song|by Cast\u00a0of the Ni.fact: “Town Meeting Song” is a song by Glenn Shadix and Danny Elfman created for the movie “The Nightmare Before Christmas.” In this song Jack has found out about Christmas Town and is telling the Halloween Town folk about it.

Jack's Obsession|by Danny\u00a0Elfman &.fact: “Jack’s Obsession” is a song by  Danny Elfman created for the movie “The Nightmare Before Christmas.” In this song, Jack is trying to understand what Christmas is and the rest of the monsters are worried about him.

Kidnap the Sandy Claws|by Danny\u00a0Elf.fact: This song is sung by Lock, Shock, and Barrel, also known as “Boogie’s Boys” (although one of them, Shock, is a girl). They have been tasked to kidnap Santa Claus by Jack Skellington, who is planning to have Halloween take over Christmas this year. The children somewhat misunderstand what they’re supposed to do, as most of their plans to “Kidnap the Sandy Claws” involve killing Santa, while Jack has said he wants Santa alive and well. It is performed by Catherine O'Hara (Shock), Paul Reubens (Lock) and Danny Elfman (Barrel).

Making Christmas|by The\u00a0Citizens of.fact:
The citizens of Halloween Town are making the toys  which Jack Skellington will be delivering as he tries to take Santa Claus' place. Little do they know that the toys they are making are scary, which does not fit the spirit of Christmas at all!

Remember, Jack doesn’t intend to scare the children of the world on Christmas Eve…

Oogie Boogie's Song|by Ken\u00a0Page, Ed.fact: This song is an introduction to the Oogie Boogie Man and what he is capable of. In the song, he expresses his feelings toward Santa Claus, or “Sandy Claws” as he said it, and implies his love for killing and or torturing his victims after hearing his Oogie Boogie Song.

Finale / Reprise|by Danny\u00a0Elfman, C.fact: This song is at the end of the Walt Disney and Tim Burton movie, “The Nightmare Before Christmas,” released in 1993. In this song, the people of Halloween Town realize that Jack Skellington, their leader, is alive after returning from Christmas Town and attempting to take over Christmas. At the end of this song, him and Sally realize they’re “simply mean to be,” and after seeing Sally’s love for Jack throughout the movie, we now see his love for her in return.

Closing.title: Closing
Closing.lyrics: And finally, everything worked out just fineChristmas was saved, though there wasn't much timeBut after that night, things were never the sameEach holiday now knew the other one's nameAnd though that one Christmas, things got out of handI'm still rather fond of that skeleton manSo, many years later, I thought I'd drop inAnd there was old Jack, still looking quite thinWith four or five skeleton children at handPlaying strange little tunes in their xylophone bandAnd I asked old Jack, "Do you remember the nightWhen the sky was so dark and the moon shone so bright?When a million small children pretending to sleepNearly didn't have Christmas at all, so to speak?And would, if you could, turn that mighty clock backTo that long, fateful night, now, think carefully, JackWould you do the whole thing all over againKnowing what you know now, knowing what you knew then?"And he smiled, like the old Pumpkin King that I knewThen turned and asked softly to me, "Wouldn't you?"

Two Worlds.fact: According to Billboard, this musical lullaby is the first song Phil Collins worked on with Mark Macina for the Disney movie “Tarzan”. The song is woven into the score and sets the musical tone and theme for the entire movie.

Son of Man.fact:
The song is infamous for the most time skipping in a Disney film. That’s because the five to seven year old Tarzan (also called ‘Kid Tarzan’, the same one also used in television flashbacks and a STV mid-prequel) remains the most popular past life stage indeed!

The basis of this song consists of Tarzan trying to fit in with his Gorilla family. But, as seen throughout him growing up, he takes on the talents of other animals – the most notable being swinging on vines like a monkey. It also consists of the transition from 5 year old Tarzan to 20, and the evolution of his friends as well. Its about his journey of growing up and him becoming a man.

I've Got a Dream|by Mandy\u00a0Moore, Br.fact:
During “I’ve Got a Dream,” the Pub Thugs sing about their various dreams. Before the song, Flynn takes Rapunzel to the “Snuggly Duckling.” While there, the Pub Thugs realize that Flynn is a wanted criminal so they surround him, wanting the reward for capturing him. Rapunzel intervenes asking if any of them have ever “had a dream!”

In an interview with Collider, the composer of Tangled said this about the song:

Mother Knows Best|Reprise by Donna\u00a0.fact: After Rapunzel heals Eugene’s hand, he leaves to get more wood for the fire. Mother Gothel then reveals herself to Rapunzel, startling her. Gothel tries to bring Rapunzel back to the tower. When this fails, Gothel gives her the tiara that Rapunzel had hidden from Eugene. She tells her that Eugene doesn’t really like Rapunzel, he is just staying with her to get the tiara back. Rapunzel denies this but later hides the tiara, afraid that Gothel was right and that Eugene would leave her if she gave him the tiara.

I See the Light|by Mandy\u00a0Moore & Za.fact: “I See the Light” is a romantic duet in Tangled between Rapunzel and Eugene. It is sung when Rapunzel is finally achieving her lifelong dream to see the floating lanterns. The song was nominated for best song at the 83rd academy awards but lost to “We Belong Together” from Toy Story 3.

Healing Incantation|by Mandy\u00a0Moore.fact:
“Healing Incantation” is a song reprised several times throughout Tangled as a spell to make a person young again or to heal. It is first sung by Mother Gothel to a flower at the beginning of the movie, causing the flower to glow and make Gothel young again. Like the flower, Rapunzel’s hair glows when the song is sung. The song is taught to Rapunzel when she is older so she can sing it to heal Mother Gothel. It is later used by Rapunzel on Eugene after he cut his hand in a cave that he and Rapunzel were trapped in.

According to Alan Menken, the composer of Tangled, this was the last song to be composed for the film.

“Kingdom Dance” is an instrumental folk song that takes place in Tangled while Rapunzel dances in her kingdom, when she arrives there for the first time, still not aware she is the princess of it.

During this song, Rapunzel comes in touch with the townspeople and shares a moment with Flynn Rider.

Something That I Want|by Grace\u00a0Pott.fact: “Something That I Want” helps bring Disney’s 2010 animated classic Tangled to a rousing finale, playing underneath the end of the film and its closing credits. It was written exclusively for the film and was both penned and performed by American pop-rock singer Grace Potter, appearing solo from her usual act with The Nocturnals. The track was released on November 16, 2010 as the final song on the Tangled Original Motion Picture Soundtrack. It became popular along with the movie’s massive success and remains one of Potter’s most streamed songs to date.

I'm Wishing / One Song|by Adriana\u00a0C.lyrics: [SNOW WHITE, spoken]Wanna know a secret?Promise not to tell?(sung)We are standing by a wishing wellMake a wish into the wellThat's all you have to doAnd if you hear it echoingYour wish will soon come trueI'm wishing (I'm wishing)For the one I loveTo find me (To find me)Today (Today)I'm hoping (I'm hoping)And I'm dreaming ofThe nice things (The nice things)He'll say (He'll say)Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah (Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah)Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah (Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah)Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah (Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah)Ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ah-ahI'm wishing (I'm wishing)For the one I loveTo find me (To find me)Today (Today)[PRINCE]Today!Now that I've found youHear what I have to sayOne song, I have but one songOne song, only for youOne heart, tenderly beatingEver entreating, constant and trueOne love that has possessed meOne love, thrilling me throughOne song, my heart keeps singingOf one love, only for you
I'm Wishing / One Song|by Adriana\u00a0C.fact:
Snow White sings her wishes of finding love into the wishing well, surrounded by her only friends, the doves.

The Prince sees her and listens to her song from a distance. When she finishes her song, he comes to the well beside her to proclaim his love for her, moved by her voice and beauty. Snow White runs away but listens from within the castle. The Evil Queen listens as well, which fuels her jealousy of Snow White.

Snow White sends the Prince a kiss through a dove.

Never Knew I Needed|by Ne-Yo.lyrics: [Verse 1]For the way you changed my plansFor being the perfect distractionFor the way you took the idea that I hadOf everything that I wanted to haveAnd made me see there was something missing, oh yeah[Verse 2]For the ending of my first beginning (Ooh, yeah yeah, ooh, yeah yeah)And for the rare and unexpected friend (Ooh, yeah yeah, ooh, yeah yeah)For the way you're something that I'd never chooseBut at the same time, something I don't wanna loseAnd never wanna be without ever again[Chorus]You're the best thing I never knew I neededSo when you were here, I had no ideaYou're the best thing I never knew I neededSo now it's so clear, I need you here always[Verse 3]My accidental happily (Ever after)The way you smile and how you comfort me (With your laughter)I must admit you were not a part of my bookBut now if you open it up and take a lookYou're the beginning and the end of every chapter[Chorus]You're the best thing I never knew I neededOh, so when you were here, I had no idea (When you were here)You're the best thing I never knew I needed (That I needed)So now it's so clear, I need you here always (Now it's so clear)[Bridge]Who knew that I could be (Who knew that I could be)So unexpectedly (So unexpectedly)Undeniably happierSitting with you right here, right here next to me[Chorus]Girl, you're the bestYou're the best thing I never knew I needed (Said I needed)So when you were here I had no idea (When you were here, said I had no idea)You're the best thing I never knew I needed (That I needed)So now it's so clear I need you here always (So clear, so clear, I need you always)[Outro]Now it's so clear, I need you here always
Never Knew I Needed|by Ne-Yo.fact: In this song, Ne-Yo is explaining how he slowly fell in love. From beginning to end, he is telling a story. At first he didn’t know they would even be compatible. By the end of the song, he knows he cannot go on with the love of his life.

Almost There|by Anika\u00a0Noni Rose.fact: “Almost There” is the main character, Tiana’s signature song in The Princess and the Frog.  In the song, she tries to explain to her mother why she works so hard. She is a young chef who works two jobs, both as a diner waitress, so she can save enough money to start her own restaurant, a dream she shared with her late father James, who presumably died in the Great War.

Friends on the Other Side|by Keith\u00a0.fact:
‘Friends on the Other Side’ is the leading antagonist, Dr. Facilier’s main and most well-known song in the film ‘The Princess and The Frog’.

The song is an interaction between the characters of Dr. Facilier, Prince Naveen and Lawrence (Naveen’s butler) in which Facilier tells their future through tarot cards.

It is during this song that Prince Naveen is tricked by Dr. Facilier and transformed into a frog.

Gonna Take You There|by Jim\u00a0Cumming.fact: After meeting the Cajun firefly Ray (clever) and learning that Louis has been taking them in the wrong direction to Mama Odie’s, Naveen and Tiana ask the bumpkin bug to help them. Steady As the Beating Drum|Reprise by Ji.fact: “Steady As The Beating Drum (Reprise)” is sung by Chief Powhatan to Pocahontas after he speaks to her about engagement with Kocoum. It reprises “Steady As The Beating Drum”, which introduced the people of the Powhatan Confederacy and Powhatan’s return home.

Colors of the Wind|Soundtrack by Judy\u0.fact: “Colors of the Wind” is a song written by lyricist Stephen Schwartz and composer Alan Menken for Walt Disney Pictures' 33rd animated feature film Pocahontas (1995). It’s the film’s theme song, originally recorded by  Judy Kuhn in her role as the singing voice of Pocahontas. But Vanessa Williams' cover of the song was released as the lead single from the film’s soundtrack on March 23, 1995. A pop ballad, the song’s lyrics contrast the priorities of European imperialism with values like respecting nature and living in harmony with the Earth’s creatures.

Savages, Pt. 1|by Chorus\u00a0- Pocahont.fact: In “Savages, Pt. 1,” the Virginian settlers and Powhatan tribe prepare to go to war after John Smith is taken prisoner by the Native Americans for killing Kocoum when he takes the blame from Thomas. Governor Ratcliffe exploits Smith’s capture to rally up his men into attacking the Powhatan so he can take the gold he believes they are standing in the way of, while the Chief gathers tribespeople from neighboring villages to attack the settlers.

If I Never Knew You|End Title by Jon\u00.fact:
“If I Never Knew You” plays through the end credits of the 1995 Disney animated film Pocahontas.

It is an R&B version of the song which was originally a duet between Pocahontas and John Smith and was cut from the original version of the film.

What Made the Red Man Red/Tinknapped|Ft..fact: In this appalling song, a group of Native American stereotypes sing about, among other things, a racial “origin” story that suggests their skin tone is the result of “blushing.” Beyond the blatant racism, this song shows how the white gaze “others” indigenous peoples, viewing non-“white” skin tones as a mere departure from the foundational (i.e., “pure”) tone of northern European skin.

Honor to Us All|by Lea\u00a0Salonga, Bet.fact: “Honor to Us All” is a song sung by Mulan’s mother, Grandmother Fa, and other women as they prepare Mulan for presentation to the matchmaker. The song was made using the pentatonic scale and Chinese flutes, as are used in traditional Chinese music.

Mulan's Decision|Synthesizer Version Sco.title: Mulan's Decision
Mulan's Decision|Synthesizer Version Sco.fact: Informally known as “Short Hair”, “Mulan’s Decision (Synthesizer Version Score)” is the 12nd track of Mulan Original Motion Picture Soundtrack and is well-known for playing during the scene in which Mulan leaves home, deciding to join the Imperial Army disguising herself as a man.

Tulou Tagaloa|by Olivia\u00a0Foa'i.fact: This ethereal song is heard over the opening logos to the movie. It is sung in the Samoan language and is a prayer to the god Tagaloa, the chief creation deity in the mythology of Samoa and other islands in the region. The song begins with a chant that is a plea to Tagaloa to listen, before asking him to look down upon the beautiful world he has created.

An Innocent Warrior|by Vai\u00a0Mahina,.fact: At this point in the movie, Moana is a toddler. After she helps a baby sea turtle reach the ocean, the ocean introduces itself and begins to play with her. Seeing Moana’s good heart and curiosity, it tries to give her the heart of Te Fiti, endowing her with the sacred task of restoring the balance of nature on the islands.

How Far I'll Go|by Auli'i\u00a0Cravalho.fact: “How Far I’ll Go” is Moana’s character-establishing “I Want” song. In a private moment of doubt, she expresses her internal struggle between her desire to stay on the island to lead as chief, and her dream of leaving the island to explore the open ocean, which has fascinated her for her whole life.

We Know the Way|by Opetaia\u00a0Foa\u201.fact: Within the movie, this song is sent as a spiritual message to Moana and can be viewed as her ancestors trying to tell her who her people truly are in their hearts. It becomes a celebration of voyaging, and the Polynesian pride that comes from being the world’s original great navigators.

How Far I'll Go|Reprise by Auli'i\u00a0C.fact: This reprise of “How Far I’ll Go” occurs as a dying Grandma Tala tells Moana to go find Maui, deliver him across the great seas, and restore the heart of Te Fiti.

You're Welcome|by Dwayne\u00a0Johnson.fact: Dwayne “The Rock” Johnson lends his voice to Disney’s animated feature film, Moana, as Maui, the Polynesian demigod who oh-so-selflessly sings “You’re Welcome” to introduce himself to the Polynesian princess. The scene features Maui’s tattoos, which showcase his legendary actions. While sweeping Moana and the listener up in his feats of strength and daring, Maui uses the song as a distraction to take Moana’s boat and leave her behind.

Shiny|by Jemaine\u00a0Clement.fact: Like all the best villain songs, this one is meant to throw a wrench into our heroine’s quest. Adding to Disney’s venerable record of hits, “Shiny” is the smug declaration of the giant crab Tamatoa that Moana’s search to find out who she is inside is meaningless. Your outside is all that matters, princess! But, then again, this is from a giant crab who doesn’t appear to get out much.

Logo Te Pate|by Olivia\u00a0Foa'i, Opeta.fact: This song actually existed prior to Moana as “Logo Te Pate.” It’s originally by Te Vaka, Opetaia Foa'i’s group that performs original music with influences from their South Pacific heritage – as they call it, “South Pacific Fusion”. The whole group is made up of eleven members, all dancers and musicians from Pacific islands. The track was reworked and shortened for the film.

Know Who You Are|by Auli'i\u00a0Cravalho.fact: After seeing that Te Fiti is “gone”, Moana realizes that Te Kā is actually Te Fiti without her heart. Moana asks the ocean to clear a path for Te Kā to approach her and, gently but confidently, Moana asks Te Kā to remember who she truly is. At the end of the scene Moana and Te Kā perform hongi, a form of greeting from New Zealand, to greet each other.

We Know the Way|Finale by Lin-Manuel\u00.fact: This song plays at the end of movie, after Moana has completed the journey that her grandmother and the ocean sent her on. We see Moana and her people setting out on a voyage, mirroring the vision that she had of her ancestors.

You're Welcome|by Jordan\u00a0Fisher.fact: American singer Jordan Fisher covers Maui’s introductory song from the film. Jordan is best known for his appearances on Disney properties like ABC Family’s The Secret Life of the American Teenager and Disney Channel’s Liv and Maddie and Teen Beach Movies, but he also caught the eye of the musical theater world playing a supporting role in Grease Live.

More|Outtake Ft.\u00a0Lin-Manuel\u00a0Mi.fact: “More” is an outtake track available on Disc 2 of the Moana soundtrack. The part of Moana is sung by Marcy Harriell, while that of her father, Chief Tui, is sung by Lin-Manuel Miranda. Harriell is a Broadway vet who performed as Mimi in Rent for over 12 years. She also performed as Vanessa in Lin-Manuel Miranda’s In The Heights from March 2008 until its closing in 2011, which is how the two became close. According to Miranda, “It was sort of all hands on deck to help me demonstrate these songs.”

Warrior Face|Outtake Ft.\u00a0Lin-Manuel.fact: “Warrior Face” is a cut song from Moana that was originally meant to happen before the scene with Tamatoa in the movie. Ultimately, it got removed because they felt that Moana and Maui were “bonding too early.”

Shiny|Demo Ft.\u00a0Lin-Manuel\u00a0Mira.fact: Lin-Manuel Miranda wrote this demo version of “Shiny,” sung by the villainous crab Tamatoa, after learning that the Moana character would be voiced by Jemaine Clement, of Flight of the Conchords fame. Inspired by the Flight of the Conchords' “Bowie” spoof, Miranda sang the demo in the style of the dearly departed David Bowie. While most of the lyrics survived in the song’s final version, sung by Clement in the film, some clever rhymes were left on the cutting-room floor.

The Life I Lead|by David\u00a0Tomlinson.lyrics: [George Banks]I feel a surge of deep satisfactionMuch as a king astride his noble steedWhen I return from daily strife to hearth and wifeHow pleasant is the life I lead![Winifred Banks, spoken]Dear, it's about the children...[Mr. Banks, spoken]Yes, yes, yes[sung]I run my home precisely on scheduleAt 6:01, I march through my doorMy slippers, sherry, and pipe are due at 6:02Consistent is the life I lead![Mrs. Banks, spoken]George, they're missing![Mr. Banks, spoken]Splendid, splendid[sung]It's grand to be an Englishman in 1910King Edward's on the throne; it's the age of menI'm the lord of my castle, the sov'reign, the liege!I treat my subjects--servants, children, wifeWith a firm but gentle hand, noblesse oblige!It's 6:03 and the heirs to my dominionAre scrubbed and tubbed and adequately fedAnd so I'll pat them on the head and send them off to bedAh, lordly is the life I lead!A British nanny must be a gen'ralThe future empire lies within her handsAnd so the person that we need to mold the breedIs a nanny who can give commands![spoken]You getting this, Winifred?[Mrs. Banks, spoken]Oh yes, dear, every word![Mr. Banks, sung]A British bank is run with precisionA British home requires nothing less!Tradition, discipline, and rules must be the toolsWithout them...Disorder! Catastrophe! Anarchy!In short, you have a ghastly mess!
The Life I Lead|by David\u00a0Tomlinson.fact: The introduction of George Banks — Father of Jane and Michael, singing about the satisfaction of running his household the way he likes it. The song demonstrates George’s admiration of detail and precision, setting up his character as a fairly stern father.

The Perfect Nanny|by Karen\u00a0Dotrice.title: The Perfect Nanny
The Perfect Nanny|by Karen\u00a0Dotrice.lyrics: [JANE, spoken]Wanted: A nanny for two adorable children.​(sung)If you want this choice positionHave a cheery dispositionRosy cheeks, no warts[MICHAEL, spoken]That's the part I put in![JANE]Play games, all sortYou must be kind, you must be wittyVery sweet and fairly prettyTake us on outings, give us treatsSing songs bring sweetsNever be cross or cruelNever give us castor oil or gruelLove us as a son and daughterAnd never smell of barley water[MICHAEL, spoken]I put that in too![JANE]If you won't scold and dominate usWe will never give you cause to hate usWe won't hide your spectacles so you can't seePut toads in your bed or pepper in your teaHurry, NannyMany thanksSincerely[BOTH]Jane and Michael Banks
The Perfect Nanny|by Karen\u00a0Dotrice.fact: Jane and Michael present to their parents an advertisement made by them for a nanny. George, however doesn’t accept it and throws it in the fireplace and burns it.

Feed the Birds|Tuppence a Bag by Julie\u.fact: “Feed The Birds” was written for the film Mary Poppins. Songwriter Robert Sherman has stated it was Walt Disney’s favorite song of all time.

Chim Chim Cher-ee|by Dick\u00a0Van Dyke.fact: The winner of the Oscar for Best Original Song, this minor-key waltz has lyrics inspired by Mary Poppins screenwriter Don DaGradi and his research into British folklore related to chimney sweeps and is sung by Bert (Dick Van Dyke), who is backed by Mary (Julie Andrews) as well as Jane and Michael (Karen Dotrice and Matthew Garber).

Step in Time|by Dick\u00a0Van Dyke.fact: A lively song and dance number — Step in Time is a “call and response” type song and dance performed by the chimney sweeps. Bert yells a dance move and lyrics out, and everyone copies it.

Daughters of Triton|by Daughters\u00a0of.fact: “Daughters of Triton” is a song composed by Sebastian to be performed by King Triton’s daughters for his birthday concert. Each daughter has a solo, including Ariel, who has the big finale. However, it’s revealed Ariel is missing as she’s off on another adventure with Flounder, introducing the first conflict of the movie.

Part of Your World|by Jodi\u00a0Benson.fact: “Part of Your World,” from the 1989 Disney animated film The Little Mermaid, sees the titular character Ariel expressing her desire to learn about and explore the human world as she swims among her collection of human artifacts in her secret grotto.

Under the Sea|Ft.\u00a0Samuel\u00a0E. Wr.fact: “Under the Sea” is an upbeat calypso track featured in the 1989 Disney animated film The Little Mermaid. Jamaican crab Sebastian sings to warn Ariel that despite her curiosity of the world above, she’s best off staying under the sea. It was inspired by “The Beautiful Briny Sea” from the 1971 film Bedknobs and Broomsticks.

Part of Your World|Reprise by Jodi\u00a0.fact: Ariel sings “Part of Your World (Reprise)” after rescuing Prince Eric from a shipwreck and reviving him. Now instead of dreaming of being part of the human world in general, Ariel wishes she could be part of Eric’s world.

Poor Unfortunate Souls|by Pat\u00a0Carro.fact: This song is from Disney’s 1989 animated feature film The Little Mermaid, sung by main antagonist Ursula (Pat Carroll) to protagonist Ariel (Jodi Benson). It combines the styles of musical theatre and Burlesque music, which Ursula uses to lure Ariel into trading her voice for the chance to become human.

Kiss the Girl|by Samuel\u00a0E. Wright.fact: Sebastian, seeing that Ariel and Eric need a little push to make true love’s kiss happen, decides to take matter into is own hands (or claws) and the direct the lagoon creatures in a calypso ballad. The song’s lyrics encourage Eric to kiss his Ariel before it is too late. If Ariel cannot get her true love, Eric, to kiss her in three days, she will turn back into a mermaid and belong to Ursula… forever.

Circle of Life|Broadway Version Ft.\u00a.fact: The idea of a “circle of life” has prevailed in almost every culture and religion.  Genesis 3:19 states “dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.”  The Perek Shirah text discusses the dignity of death and how our bodies provide life.  Native American culture represents this relationship in the symbolic “medicine wheel.”  This universal philosophy is presented by Elton John and Tim Rice in the animated movie and the musical. Circles feature throughout the musical, starting with the circular sun that rises at the beginning.

The Morning Report|Ft.\u00a0Geoff\u00a0H.fact:
“The Morning Report” was originally written for the 1994 movie The Lion King, but was cut.

For the Special Edition DVD of the movie released in 2003, the song was fully animated and inserted into the film, although an option was given to watch the “original” cut of the film as well.

I Just Can't Wait to Be King|Broadway Ve.fact: In this fast-paced, upbeat song with arguably some of the most colourful staging in the show, young Simba expresses his excitement for when it is his time to take over the throne. He and his friend Nala use the song to distract Zazu in order to escape his watch and head to the Elephant Graveyard by themselves. The two of them succeed, and Zazu not only loses his puppet but is also forcibly separated from the two cubs by the stage curtain at the end of the song. At that point Zazu usually breaks the fourth wall,  lamenting to the audience about the loss of his puppet and also being snarky about the appearance of the stage curtain itself. In the West End production he has been known to remark:

Chow Down|Ft.\u00a0Kevin\u00a0Cahoon, St.fact: Simba and Nala find themselves in the Elephant Graveyard where they are confronted by the hyenas Shenzi, Banzai, and Ed. The three scavengers sing a song about how they plan to devour the two lion cubs.

They Live in You|Ft.\u00a0Samuel\u00a0E..fact: Mufasa rescues Simba and Nala from the hyenas in the Elephant Graveyard just in time. Simba is scared of the punishment he will receive for disobeying his father, but the gentle and kindly Mufasa explains that his harshness is because he was scared for his son’s life and that “being brave doesn’t mean you go looking for trouble”. After Mufasa plays with his son, Simba asks if they’ll always be together. Mufasa explains that the Great Kings of the Past will always watch over them, as will he.

The Stampede.fact: Scar tells Simba to sit down and wait in the gorge, telling the cub that his father Mufasa has “a marvellous surprise” waiting and that it’s “… to die for.” Scar then leaves Simba and instructs the waiting hyenas to startle some nearby wildebeest to stampede into the gorge, causing Simba to become trapped. Scar then informs Mufasa that the cub is in peril. Mufasa leaps into the gorge and saves his son, but as he attempts to climb out of the gorge his brother Scar throws him back in, leading to the king’s death.

Rafiki Mourns|Ft.\u00a0Tsidii\u00a0Le Lo.fact: Mufasa, a much-loved king, is dead. Scar, believing his plan to have been successful, tricks both the royal pride and the residents of the Pride Lands into believing that the young prince Simba has died as well. Rafiki and the lionesses mourn these terrible and devastating losses.

Hakuna Matata|Ft.\u00a0Jason\u00a0Raize,.fact: Timon and Pumbaa rescue Simba from the desert and take the lion cub to their jungle home. Simba is reluctant to talk about his past and where he came from, so Timon and Pumbaa explain their philosophy for life: “Hakuna Matata – no worries, no problems!”

One|by One.fact: This song originally featured on the 1995 album Rhythm of the Pride Lands. It was also used in a 2004 animated short that was an extra feature on the special edition DVD release of The Lion King II: Simba’s Pride.

Madness of King Scar|Ft.\u00a0Geoff\u00a.fact: Scar has everything he’s ever wanted – the Pride Lands and a pride of royal lionesses – and yet it’s not at all what he expected. Instead of the adoration that was heaped upon his brother Mufasa, Scar finds that the lionesses don’t seem to appreciate him at all.

Shadowland|Ft.\u00a0Heather\u00a0Headley.fact: Nala, having tried to reason with Scar to no avail, realises that she has to leave the Pride Lands and find help. She despairs at leaving her pride, but knows that she has no choice. Rafiki and the royal pride offer their blessings to the young lioness as she sets off on her journey.

Can You Feel the Love Tonight?|Ft.\u00a0.fact: Simba can’t believe that his friend Nala has left the Pride Lands and come to the jungle. As the two lions reminisce they realise that their childhood friendship has blossomed into romance.

He Lives in You|Reprise Ft.\u00a0Jason\u.fact: This song takes on a poignant meaning as a reprise of “They Live in You”, a song sung by Mufasa to Simba to explain the Great Kings of the Past. This time Rafiki uses the meaning to explain that Mufasa is now one of the Great Kings of the Past and that his spirit lives on in Simba.

Simba Confronts Scar.title: Simba Confronts Scar
Simba Confronts Scar.fact: Simba has returned to the Pride Lands with Nala and his friends Timon and Pumbaa by his side. He witnesses Scar angrily ask Sarabi why she isn’t out hunting, with Sarabi explaining that there is no food or water and that they should leave Pride Rock if the pride is to survive. Scar is dismissive and refuses, prompting Sarabi to say that Scar is nothing like his brother Mufasa. Scar explodes with rage and strikes Sarabi, which angers Simba and causes him to leap to his mother’s defense.

King of Pride Rock/Circle of Life|Repris.fact: After a fierce battle, Scar is defeated and Simba can now take his place as the rightful king. Rafiki gives Simba the mantle of kingship (it is a literal mantle, but also signifies him taking on the role of king) as he ascends Pride Rock and roars out across the kingdom in triumph. The lionesses and animals of the Pride Lands gather and sing in jubilation.

Circle of Life|by Carmen\u00a0Twillie &.fact: Lebo M’s arresting and enthralling Zulu chant opens the movie and calls to the citizens of the Pride Lands to come to Pride Rock. As the sun rises, the animals of the Pride Lands awaken from their slumber and begin to journey across the landscape. The music gently swells behind Carmen Twillie’s vocals until, suddenly, Pride Rock comes into view and we hear the first chorus.

I Just Can't Wait to be King|Ft.\u00a0Ja.lyrics: [SIMBA]I'm gonna be a mighty king, so enemies beware![ZAZU]Well, I've never seen a king of beasts with quite so little hair[SIMBA]I'm gonna be the main event, like no king was beforeI'm brushing up on looking down, I'm working on my roar![ZAZU]Thus far, a rather... uninspiring thing[SIMBA]Oh, I just can't wait to be king![ZAZU]You've rather a long way to go, young master, if you think...[SIMBA]No one saying do this[ZAZU]Now when I said that, I -[NALA]No one saying be there[ZAZU]What I meant was...[SIMBA]No one saying stop that[ZAZU]Look, what you don't realize...[SIMBA & NALA]No one saying see here[ZAZU]Now see here![SIMBA]Free to run around all day[ZAZU]Well, that's definitely out[SIMBA]Free to do it all my way![ZAZU]I think it's time that you and I arranged a heart to heart[SIMBA]Kings don't need advice from little hornbills for a start[ZAZU]If this is where the monarchy is headed, count me out!Out of service, out of Africa - I wouldn't hang about... aagh!This child is getting wildly out of wing[SIMBA]Oh, I just can't wait to be king!Everybody look leftEverybody look rightEverywhere you look I'm standing in the spotlight![ZAZU]Not yet![ANIMALS]Let every creature go for broke and singLet's hear it in the herd and on the wingIt's gonna be King Simba's finest fling[ANIMALS & SIMBA]Oh, I just can't wait to be king!Oh, I just can't wait to be king!Oh I just can't wait... to be king!
I Just Can't Wait to be King|Ft.\u00a0Ja.fact: Simba gains permission from his mother to take his friend Nala to see “the watering hole”, but unknown to their parents he really plans to go to the dangerous and forbidden Elephant Graveyard. However, with Zazu the hornbill babysitting the pair, the two cubs need to hatch a plan to distract the bird so they can escape. Simba decides to prove to Zazu that he will indeed by a good king despite the bird’s protests, and on the opening beat of the song the Pride Lands turn into a colorful playground in which Simba, Nala, and the animals of the Pride Lands can have some fun.

Be Prepared|Ft.\u00a0Cheech\u00a0Marin,.fact: In this classic villain song from the 1994 Disney animated film The Lion King, chief antagonist Scar explains to his hyena minions his plan to kill his brother Mufasa and nephew Simba, thus thwarting the line of succession in order to for him to become king.

Can You Feel the Love Tonight|Ft.\u00a0E.fact: During “Can You Feel the Love Tonight,” Timon and Pumbaa mourn for their diminishing friendship with Simba while off-screen vocals sing about the romance in the air. Simba and Nala walk and playfully wrestle throughout the jungle while beginning to fall in love. The song won an Oscar and Golden Globe for Best Original Song in 1994.

Can You Feel the Love Tonight|End Title.fact: An alternate version of the song of the same name from the 1994 Disney animated film The Lion King. This version is a piano-driven soft rock ballad by famed English singer-songwriter Elton John, who also composed many songs for the movie. It was the end credits song of the movie as well as a well-charted single in its own right, peaking at #4 on the US Billboard Top 100 as well as topping the US Hot Adult Contemporary and France’s SNEP charts.

The Bare Necessities|by Phil\u00a0Harris.title: The Bare Necessities
The Bare Necessities|by Phil\u00a0Harris.lyrics: [Spoken Intro: Baloo]All you gotta do is...[Chorus: Baloo]Look for the bare necessitiesThe simple bare necessitiesForget about your worries and your strifeI mean the bare necessitiesOld Mother Nature's recipesThat bring the bare necessities of life[Verse 1: Baloo]Wherever I wander, wherever I roamI couldn't be fonder of my big homeThe bees are buzzin' in the treeTo make some honey just for meWhen you look under the rocks and plantsAnd take a glance at the fancy antsThen maybe try a few[Skit: Baloo, Mowgli & Bagheera]You eat ants?Hahaha, you gotta believe itAnd you're gonna love the way they tickleMowgli, look out![Pre-Chorus: Baloo & Mowgli]The bare necessities of life will come to you (When?)They'll come to you[Chorus: Baloo]Look for the bare necessitiesThe simple bare necessitiesForget about your worries and your strifeI mean the bare necessitiesThat's why a bear can rest at easeWith just the bare necessities of life[Verse 2: Baloo & Mowgli]Now when you pick a pawpawOr a prickly pear (Ow!)And you prick a raw pawNext time bewareDon't pick the prickly pear by the pawWhen you pick a pearTry to use the clawBut you don't need to use the clawWhen you pick a pear of the big pawpawHave I given you a clue?(Golly, thanks Baloo!)[Skit: Bagheera & Baloo]Paw-paw, ha! Of all the silly gibberishC'mon Baggy, get with the beat![Pre-Chorus: Baloo & Mowgli]The bare necessities of life will come to you(They'll come to me!)They'll come to you[Interlude: Baloo & Mowgli]How about scratchin' that ol' left shoulder while you're up there, Mowgli?Now just a hair lower.. There, right there. That's it. Ahh..This is beautiful. That's good. Kid, we've got to get to a treeThis calls for some big scratch!You're lots of fun, Baloo!Right on it.. Yeah! That's delicious! Oh, ooo! Just a little bit--Mmm.. yeah.. ha-ha.. oooMm... mmm... ha-ha.. ooo. yeah!Oh man, this is really livin'[Bridge: Baloo]So just try and relax, yeah, cool itFall apart in my backyard'Cause let me tell you something, little britchesIf you act like that bee acts, uh-uhYou're working too hardAnd don't spend your time lookin' aroundFor something you want that can't be foundWhen you find out you can live without itAnd go along not thinkin' about itI'll tell you something trueThe bare necessities of life will come to you[Skit: Bagheera & Baloo]Ahh.. I give up. Well I hope his luck holds outMowgli, how 'bout you singing?[Chorus: Baloo, Mowgli & Both]Look for the bare necessitiesThe simple bare necessitiesForget about your worries and your strife(Yeah, man!)I mean the bare necessitiesOld Mother Nature's recipesThat bring the bare necessities of life(Yeah!)With just the bare necessities of lifeYeah, man!
The Bare Necessities|by Phil\u00a0Harris.fact: From Disney’s 1967 animated film The Jungle Book, anthropomorphic bear Baloo expounds upon Mowgli the importance of taking it easy. Essentially a precursor to Hakuna Matata.

for the softer side of Agrabah[COMPANY]Arabian Nights...Arabian Nights[GENIE]And of course, you must watchYour step here in AgrabahFor danger lurks aroundEvery corner and ugly bad guys too[COMPANY]Arabian Nights[GENIE]It's a city where a penniless nobodyCan turn out to be...A noble somebody[COMPANY]Arabian Nights[GENIE]It's a place where a princessWould give up her crown for true One Jump Ahead|Ft.\u00a0Adam\u00a0Jacobs.lyrics: [ALADDIN]Gotta keepOne jump ahead of the breadlineOne swing ahead of the swordI steal only what I can't affordAnd that's everythingOne jump ahead of the lawmenThat's all and that's no jokeThese guys don't appreciate I'm broke[GUARDS]RiffraffStreet ratScoundrelTake that[ALADDIN]Just a little snack, guys[GUARDS]Rip him open, take it back, guys[ALADDIN]I can take a hint, gotta face the factsI could use a friend or two[ALL]True[LADIES]Oh, it's sad, Aladdin's hit the bottomHe's become a one man rise in crimeI'd blame parents, except he hasn't got 'em[ALADDIN]Gotta eat to live, gotta steal to eatTell you all about it when I got the timeOne jump ahead of the slowpokesOne skip ahead of my doomNext time gonna use a nom de plumeOne jump ahead of the hitmenOne hit ahead of the flockI think I'll take a stroll around the block[TRADERS]Stop, thiefVandalOutrageScandal[ALADDIN]Let's not be too hasty[WOMAN]Still I think he's rather tasty[ALADDIN]Gotta eat to live, gotta steal to eatOtherwise we'd get along[ALL]Wrong[ALADDIN]One jump ahead of the hoofbeats[GUARDS]Vandal[ALADDIN]One hop ahead of the hump[GUARDS]Street rat[ALADDIN]One trick ahead of disaster[GUARDS]Scoundrel[ALADDIN]They're quick, but I'm much faster[GUARDS]Take that[ALADDIN]Here goes, better throw my hand inWish me happy landin' all I gotta do is jump[GUARDS]Don't let him get away[ALADDIN, spoken]Sometimes it's just way too easy
One Jump Ahead|Ft.\u00a0Adam\u00a0Jacobs.fact: One Just Ahead is the Broadway adaption of One Jump Ahead, featured in the original film. This version keeps most of the original lyrics, but removes lines about Abu and adds lines from the ensemble.

These Palace Walls|Ft.\u00a0Courtney\u00.fact: In “These Palace Walls,” Jasmine expresses the insincerity of her suitors and displeasure with royal courting. She thinks about exploring past the palace walls and her attendants encourage her to step outside of her sheltered life.

Babkak, Omar, Aladdin, Kassim|Ft.\u00a0A.fact: Originally written for the Aladdin movie, this song was cut when the team decided to use Abu the monkey in the place of Aladdin’s friends. The song was later repurposed into this one, to be used for the stage musical.

A Million Miles Away|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: In this song, Aladdin and Jasmine both connect over feeling trapped in their daily lives, but both want what the other wants to leave behind. Aladdin wants luxury and riches, while Jasmine feels confined in the palace and wants freedom. Despite this, they both dream about running far away and begin to fall in love.

Prince Ali|Jafar Reprise by Alan\u00a0Me.fact: Turning Aladdin’s hero song on its head, Jafar reveals Prince Ali’s true identity to Jasmine. This song marks a major turning point, as it seems all hope is lost and Jafar has won.

Arabian Nights|by Bruce\u00a0Adler.lyrics: [PEDDLER]Oh, I come from a land, from a faraway placeWhere the caravan camels roamWhere it's flat and immense and the heat is intenseIt's barbaric, but hey, it's homeWhen the wind's from the east and the sun's from the westAnd the sand in the glass is rightCome on down, stop on by, hop a carpet and flyTo another Arabian nightArabian nights, like Arabian daysMore often than not are hotter than hotIn a lot of good waysArabian nights 'neath Arabian moonsA fool off his guard could fall and fall hardOut there on the dunes
Arabian Nights|by Bruce\u00a0Adler.fact: The opening song of Disney’s 1992 animated film Aladdin, and subsequently the opening track of its soundtrack album. “Arabian Nights” sets the stage of the film by having Bruce Adler as The Peddler singing about the wonders and dangers that lie within this setting.

Legend of the Lamp|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fullTitle: Legend of the Lamp by Alan Menken
Legend of the Lamp|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Legend of the Lamp
Legend of the Lamp|by Alan\u00a0Menken.lyrics: [PEDDLERMAN, spoken]Ah, Salaam and Good Evening to you, my dear friendPlease, please come closer...[Camera hits Peddler]Ah uh, too close, a little to close...[Camera pulls back]There. Welcome to Agrabah, city of mystery, of enchantment...[takes out a table full of stuff]And the finest merchandise this side of the River Jordan, on sale today! Come on down, heh heh... Look at this, yes, he heCombination hooka and coffee maker, also makes julienne fries! It will not break! It will not... It brokeOh, look at this, I have never seen one of these intact before... This is the famous Dead Sea Tupperware. Listen *pfft* ah, still good. Ha ha[Camera starts leaving]Wait, don't go! I can see that you are only interested in the exceptionally rare. I think, then, you will be most rewarded to consider this[Takes out a lamp]Do not be fooled by its common-place appearance. Like so many things, it is not what is outside, but what is inside thatCounts. This is no ordinary lamp! It once changed the course ofA young man's life. A young man, who like this lamp, was more than what he seemed... A diamond in the rough
Legend of the Lamp|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: After arriving in a camel while singing “Arabian Nights”, the Peddler changes his voice from Bruce Adler to Robin Williams – Williams couldn’t hold some of the high notes the song required, so he was reduced to just the speaking part – and introduces the plot of Aladdin to audiences.

One Jump Ahead|by Brad\u00a0Kane.fact: “One Jump Ahead” from Disney’s 1992 animated film Aladdin introduces the title character as a poor boy who has to steal from others in order to survive. These ventures leave him narrowly escaping the sword of the law at every turn.

One Jump Ahead|Reprise by Brad\u00a0Kane.fact: In this short reprise of “One Jump Ahead” from Disney’s 1992 animated film Aladdin Aladdin reacts to the things the guards and townspeople have called him and expresses that he’s more than meets the eye. The reprise is a slower, more melancholy tune to match the more somber mood.

Friend Like Me|by Robin\u00a0Williams.fact: A big, bold introduction befitting Robin Williams' energetic Genie, “Friend Like Me” not only introduces the character to Aladdin, but the audience as well. Entertaining and informative, the song explains just all that the Genie is capable of, and in a catchy Broadway style, too.

Prince Ali|by Robin\u00a0Williams.fact: After discovering the lamp and thus earning the services of the magical showboat that is Genie, Aladdin employs him to provide a princely parade, so that Aladdin might best present his suit for marriage to Princess Jasmine to the Sultan of Agrabah.

A Whole New World|by Lea\u00a0Salonga &.fact: “A Whole New World” is a Aladdin and Jasmine’s magical love ballad where they sing about the thrill of exploring the world together on a magic carpet. The song is the main musical centerpiece of the movie and in the years since Aladdin’s release, it has become one of Disney’s most famous songs.

A Whole New World|Aladdin's Theme by Pea.fact: An alternate version of “A Whole New World” from Disney’s 1992 animated film Aladdin. This version is a pop/R&B duet performed by singers Peabo Bryson and Regina Belle. It was the end credits song of the movie as well as a chart-topping single of its own, dethroning Whitney Houston’s cover of “I Will Always Love You.” The lyrics are the same as the one performed during the movie.

Prince Ali|by Will\u00a0Smith.fact: “Prince Ali” is the sixth song in the 2019 live action remake but is actually the fourth song to be sung in the movie.

A Whole New World|by Mena\u00a0Massoud &.fact: This version of ‘A Whole New World’ features in the 2019 live-action Aladdin film. Written by Alan Menken and Tim Rice, it was made for the original film of the same name; Aladdin (1992).

Speechless|Full by Naomi\u00a0Scott.fact: Princess Jasmine (Naomi Scott) is placed under arrest by the new sultan of Agrabah, Jafar (Marwan Kenzari). As she’s being led away by the guards, she reflects on a lifetime of having men tell her that her opinion is invalid or never wanted. She determines not to stay silent this time, with her kingdom being taken over by a dictator.

The Big Ship|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fullTitle: The Big Ship by Alan Menken
The Big Ship|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: The Big Ship

Aladdin's Hideout|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Aladdin's Hideout
Aladdin's Hideout|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: Aladdin (Mena Massoud) takes Jasmine (Naomi Scott) up to his humble apartment that’s hidden from street level. He offers her tea, and they talk about the state of Agrabah’s people. He guesses from her clothes that she works at the royal palace. She does not tell him that she is the princess, instead giving her maid’s name.

Jasmine Meets Prince Anders|by Alan\u00a.fullTitle: Jasmine Meets Prince Anders by Alan Menken
Jasmine Meets Prince Anders|by Alan\u00a.title: Jasmine Meets Prince Anders
Jasmine Meets Prince Anders|by Alan\u00a.fact: Jasmine (Naomi Scott) decks herself out in a fine dress to meet Prince Anders (Billy Magnussen), who has come to Agrabah with an entourage and lavish gifts to seek her hand in marriage. Jafar (Marwan Kenzari) wants the marriage to foster a political union, but the stupid and vain prince makes a bad impression on Jasmine.

Breaking In|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Breaking In
Breaking In|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: Still under the impression that Jasmine (Naomi Scott) is merely a maid in the royal palace, Aladdin (Mena Massoud) uses his skills as a thief to slip past the palace guards and reaches the door of the princess' bedchamber.

Returning the Bracelet|by Alan\u00a0Menk.fullTitle: Returning the Bracelet by Alan Menken
Returning the Bracelet|by Alan\u00a0Menk.title: Returning the Bracelet
Returning the Bracelet|by Alan\u00a0Menk.fact: Aladdin (Mena Massoud) returns the jeweled bracelet to Jasmine (Naomi Scott) that his monkey Abu stole from her in order to prove to her that he did not steal from her. Jasmine keeps up the pretense that she’s only a maid and addresses her maid (Nasim Pedrad) as if she’s the princess.

The Dunes|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: The Dunes
The Dunes|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: Jafar (Marwan Kenzari) has captured Aladdin (Mena Massoud) sneaking out of the princess' bedchamber and escorts him with an armed guard across a desert landscape.

Simple Oil Lamp|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fullTitle: Simple Oil Lamp by Alan Menken
Simple Oil Lamp|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Simple Oil Lamp
Simple Oil Lamp|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: Jafar (Marwan Kenzari) instructs Aladdin (Mena Massoud) to go into the Cave of Wonders, take an ordinary-looking oil lamp, and bring it out to him. He warns that there will be great treasures in the cave, but Aladdin must not touch them.

The Cave of Wonders|2019 by Alan\u00a0Me.fullTitle: The Cave of Wonders (2019) by Alan Menken
The Cave of Wonders|2019 by Alan\u00a0Me.title: The Cave of Wonders

The Basics|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: The Basics
The Basics|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: The genie (Will Smith) is frustrated when, after he has sung “Friend Like Me,” Aladdin (Mena Massoud) still fails to grasp the concept of being granted three wishes. The genie therefore reviews the ground rules of what Aladdin can and can’t get from his wishes.

Escape From the Cave|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fullTitle: Escape From the Cave by Alan Menken
Escape From the Cave|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Escape From the Cave
Escape From the Cave|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: The entrance to the cave has sealed shut, but the genie (Will Smith) transports Aladdin (Mena Massoud) and Abu outside into the desert. The genie thinks this is Aladdin using one of his wishes, but Aladdin points out a technicality that restores the first of his three wishes.

Prince Ali's Outfit|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fullTitle: Prince Ali's Outfit by Alan Menken
Prince Ali's Outfit|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Prince Ali's Outfit
Prince Ali's Outfit|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: Aladdin (Mena Massoud) wishes himself a wealthy prince so that he can woo Jasmine (Naomi Scott). The genie (Will Smith) sets about making Aladdin into the fictional Prince Ali, trying and rejecting several outfit choices before settling on one that looks suitably princelike.

Aladdin\u2019s Second Wish|by Alan\u00a0.fullTitle: Aladdin’s Second Wish by Alan Menken
Aladdin\u2019s Second Wish|by Alan\u00a0.title: Aladdin’s Second Wish

Never Called a Master Friend|by Alan\u00.fullTitle: Never Called a Master Friend by Alan Menken
Never Called a Master Friend|by Alan\u00.title: Never Called a Master Friend

Jafar Becomes Sultan|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fullTitle: Jafar Becomes Sultan by Alan Menken
Jafar Becomes Sultan|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Jafar Becomes Sultan
Jafar Becomes Sultan|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: Now in possession of the lamp, Jafar (Marwan Kenzari) uses his first wish to strip royal power away from the sultan (Navid Negahban) and bestow it on himself. The genie (Will Smith) has no choice but to comply.

Hakim's Loyalty Tested|by Alan\u00a0Menk.fullTitle: Hakim's Loyalty Tested by Alan Menken
Hakim's Loyalty Tested|by Alan\u00a0Menk.title: Hakim's Loyalty Tested

Most Powerful Sorcerer|by Alan\u00a0Menk.fullTitle: Most Powerful Sorcerer by Alan Menken
Most Powerful Sorcerer|by Alan\u00a0Menk.title: Most Powerful Sorcerer

Jafar Summons the Storm|by Alan\u00a0Men.fullTitle: Jafar Summons the Storm by Alan Menken
Jafar Summons the Storm|by Alan\u00a0Men.title: Jafar Summons the Storm

Jafar's Final Wish|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fullTitle: Jafar's Final Wish by Alan Menken
Jafar's Final Wish|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Jafar's Final Wish
Jafar's Final Wish|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: Aladdin (Mena Massoud) is now at the mercy of Jafar (Marwan Kenzari), but he reminds Jafar that the genie (Will Smith) will always be more powerful than him. An incensed Jafar uses his final wish to make himself the most powerful being in the world. The genie happily complies and turns Jafar into another genie, doomed to be trapped in his own lamp until a master comes along.

Genie Set Free|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fullTitle: Genie Set Free by Alan Menken
Genie Set Free|by Alan\u00a0Menken.title: Genie Set Free
Genie Set Free|by Alan\u00a0Menken.fact: The genie (Will Smith) expects Aladdin (Mena Massoud) to use his third wish to change the laws in Agrabah to allow him to marry Jasmine (Naomi Scott). However, Aladdin surprises the genie by wishing for him to be set free from the lamp. The genie becomes a human being, with his free will restored to him. He is grateful.

Friend Like Me|Finale by Alan\u00a0Menke.fullTitle: Friend Like Me (Finale) by Alan Menken (Ft. Will Smith)
Friend Like Me|Finale by Alan\u00a0Menke.title: Friend Like Me
Friend Like Me|Finale by Alan\u00a0Menke.lyrics: [Instrumental][Outro]You ain't never had a friend like me!

The Bells of Notre Dame|by Chorus,\u00a0.fact: This is the film’s first song, and it does not disappoint. The song acts as a prologue, sets the mood of the film and gives background of the hero and villain, Quasimodo and Judge Claude Frollo. The song is mainly sung and narrated by Clopin, a gypsy street performer. He’s singing this song to nearby kids, and to an extension, the audience.

Someday|by All-4-One.fact: “Someday” is the end-credits song for the 1996 animated Disney film “The Hunchback of Notre Dame”, performed by the group All-4-One. The song’s lyrics focus somewhat subtly on the film’s themes of tolerance and acceptance, with its lyrics acting as a pray for the world to one day improve and turn into a better place.

Some Things Never Change|by Josh\u00a0Ga.fact: In the second number of the film, the audience is re-introduced to the characters Anna (Kristen Bell), Kristoff (Jonathan Groff), Sven (also Groff) and Olaf (Josh Gad), one-by-one. Anna compares the changing seasons to the ways that their lives will always stay the same through ways they’ll always be together to Olaf. Meanwhile, Kristoff plans his engagement to Anna with the help of Sven. Then we meet again with Elsa (Indina Menzel) who is still wondering about the voice she hears at the very beginning of the movie. She chooses to ignore it though, and leaves to “seize the day” with the vibrant people of Arendelle who are going about their lives, and her friends.

When I Am Older|by Josh\u00a0Gad.fact: When Olaf (voiced by Josh Gad) is departed from the group in the woods, he is attacked by the spirits, but tries to assume his disposition from earlier in the film that everything is okay and that it will make sense when he’s older and therefore wiser, in order to stay calm, all while the attacks become gradually more violent. Olaf explains in the lyrics of the song that he thinks that “grown-ups” must know everything, and he’ll have to wait until he’s older to understand and be okay with all of the magical events happening around him, and that he’s only scared right now because he’s young and ignorant, or so he thinks.

Reindeer(s) Are Better Than People|Cont..fact: Kristoff, (Jonathan Groff) dismayed by the news that Anna (Kristen Bell) has left him, sadly sings to Sven (also Jonathan Groff) in the tune and words of the song “Reindeers are Better Than People” from the first film, Frozen, that love is hard. Sven, fully singing the words instead of Kristoff “voicing” them as per usual, responds with words of advice for his friend.

Lost in the Woods|by Jonathan\u00a0Groff.fact: Once again left alone by Anna (voiced by Kristen Bell) as she goes chasing after Elsa (voiced by Idina Menzel), Kristoff (voiced by Jonathan Groff) expresses his feelings of frustration at not being needed. The Next Right Thing|by Kristen\u00a0Bel.lyrics: [Verse 1: Anna]I've seen dark beforeBut not like thisThis is coldThis is emptyThis is numbThe life I knew is overThe lights are outHello, darknessI'm ready to succumb[Verse 2: Anna]I follow you aroundI always haveBut you've gone to a place I cannot findThis grief has a gravityIt pulls me downBut a tiny voice whispers in my mind"You are lost, hope is goneBut you must go onAnd do the next right thing"[Verse 3: Anna]Can there be a day beyond this night?I don't know anymore what is trueI can't find my direction, I'm all aloneThe only star that guided me was youHow to rise from the floorWhen it's not you I'm rising for?Just do the next right thingTake a step, step againIt is all that I can to doThe next right thing[Bridge: Anna]I won't look too far aheadIt's too much for me to takeBut break it down to this next breathThis next stepThis next choice is one that I can make[Verse 4: Anna]So I'll walk through this nightStumbling blindly toward the lightAnd do the next right thingAnd with the dawn, what comes thenWhen it's clear that everything will never be the same again?Then I'll make the choiceTo hear that voiceAnd do the next right thing
The Next Right Thing|by Kristen\u00a0Bel.fact: After Olaf (Josh Gad) melts away in Anna’s (Kristen Bell) arms, she curls up in a cave and almost succumbs to the grief and sadness she feels over the apparent deaths of Olaf and Elsa (Idina Menzel). In the darkest moment of the movie, she searches for the strength to overcome her despair, which is especially difficult, for almost everything she did in her life was for the sake of her sister, Elsa, and with her absence, it seems like nothing can be good again. But, as shown in this song, by relying on the former words of Pabbie (Ciarán Hinds) the troll, to do “the next right thing,“ Anna gathers enough willpower to make her way out of the cave and save her sister.

Into the Unknown|Panic! at the Disco Ver.fact: “Into the Unknown” is a cover of the soundtrack’s lead song from the animated Disney musical Frozen II (2019). The song was released by American band Panic! at the Disco as the album’s first single roughly two weeks before the film’s November 22, 2019, release date.

This song has a hidden message and here it is,

In her waters, deep and true

Lie the answers and a path for you

Dive down deep into her sound

But not too far or you’ll be drowned. This means that you can’t go to far or you will not get what you are looking for.

Love Is An Open Door|by Kristen\u00a0Bel.fact: The song is written as an apparent love duet between Anna and Hans. It begins with Anna explaining her loneliness by being shut out from Elsa for years, with Hans promising to never shut her out. As the night goes on, the two gradually find themselves sharing a lot in common, and towards the end of the night, Hans proposes to Anna, and she accepts.

Reindeer(s) Are Better Than People|by Jo.fact:
This song happens after Oaken tries to make Kristoff pay more money than he has on his person at the moment for his carrots (for Sven), pickaxe and rope. They can’t reach a compromise, and Kristoff calls Oaken a crook. Oaken does not like being called a crook, so he literally tosses Kristoff out into the cold. Kristoff then seeks shelter with Sven in a nearby stable.

This song illustrates Kristoff’s unique relationship with Sven. He is a shy, isolated man who can only be himself when around his pet reindeer. From Director notes “Kristoff’s only friend is his reindeer Sven and he rejects the human race in favor of his pet (“every one of them’s bad,” he sings in ‘Reindeer Are Better Than People’)”.

A Little Bit of You|Ft.\u00a0Audrey\u00a.fact: In this song, it replays the scene from the movie where Anna and Elsa sneak into the grand hall and turn it into a winter wonderland, introducing (in a way) the character Olaf. In this version, they stay in the bedroom and build Olaf from previous ice pieces Elsa already made, and just like in the movie, she loses control of her powers and hits Anna in the head, setting up the next years until her coronation.

What Do You Know About Love?|Ft.\u00a0Je.fact: “What Do You Know About Love?” is Anna and Kristoff’s new duet, written specifically for the Broadway production. This song details a disagreement between the two. Kristoff believes Anna should not marry Hans, as she knows almost nothing about him and just met him. Anna believes she knows what she’s doing and thinks this is true love. She does not want to listen to Kristoff since she thinks he does not know anything about love. As their back-and-forth ensues, Kristoff nearly injures himself, but Anna saves him.

In Summer|Ft.\u00a0Greg\u00a0Hildreth.fact: Olaf expresses his desire to be in summer. Olaf, a talking snowman, is oblivious to the fact that if he is exposed to heat he will melt, and therefore this song creates the comical sense to it.

Hans of the Southern Isles|Reprise Ft.\u.fact: Following Elsa’s melt-down, in which she exposes to the people of Arendelle, including her sister, her ice powers, she decides to run away to the mountains. Her sister, Anna, decides to go after her, leaving Hans in charge. In this song, he persuades the people of Arendelle to let him lead them during “this time of trials.”

For the First Time in Forever|Reprise Ft.fact: A month before closing on Broadway, this song was replaced by “I Can’t Lose You,” which was also used for the national tour. Elsa’s opening stanza was kept the same, though.

Kristoff Lulla|by.lyrics: [KRISTOFF]What is this hollow kind of helplessness I'm feeling?This type of terror is newAnd the fact that I can hardly breathe is now revealingHow much I've changed 'cause of youYou light the world for meYou live life fearlesslyBraver than the bravest of us doYou trust, you hope, you dareYou choose to feel and careI thought that I was strong till I bumped into youWhat do I know about love?What do I know about love?Everything I thought I didYou've gone and changed it kidYou're what I know about love
Kristoff Lulla|by.fact:
This song is about Kristoff discovering his love for Anna. Of course, true love reveals it’s self only in times of desperation.

The “hollow kind of helpless feeling” is because love is a two way street and both Kristoff and Anna believe that Hans is Anna’s true love, even if Kristoff loves her.

Monster|Ft.\u00a0Caissie\u00a0Levy & Joh.lyrics: [ELSA]It's finally come, come to knock down my doorI can't hide this time like I hid beforeThe storm is awake, the danger is realMy time's running out, don't feel, don't feel"Fear will be your enemyAnd death its consequence"That's what they once said to meAnd it's starting to make senseAll this pain, all this fear began because of meIs the thing they see, the thing I have to beA monster, were they right?Has the dark in me finally come to light?Am I a monster full of rageNowhere to go but on a rampage?Or am I just a monster in a cage?[HANS & MALE ENSEMBLE]End this winter, bring back summerKeep your guard up[HANS]No harm comes to her[HANS & MALE ENSEMBLE]End this winter, bring back summerKeep your guard up[ELSA]What do I do?No time for crying nowI've started a storm, gotta stop it somehowDo I keep on running?How far do I have to go?And will that take the storm awayOr only make it grow?I'm making my world colderHow long can it survive?Is everyone in danger as long as I'm alive?Was I a monster from the start?How did I end up with this frozen heart?Bringing destruction to the stageCaught in a war that I never meant to wageDo I kill the monster?Father, you know what's best for meIf I die, will they be free?Mother, what if after I'm goneThe cold gets colder and the storm rages on?No!I have to stay alive to fix what I've doneSave the world from myselfAnd bring back the sunIf I'm a monster, then it's trueThere's only one thing that's left for me to doBut before I fade to whiteI'll do all that I can to make things rightI cannot be a monsterI will not be a monsterNot tonight!
Monster|Ft.\u00a0Caissie\u00a0Levy & Joh.fact: “Monster” details Elsa in a moment of intense anxiety. She no longer feels as free as she did in “Let  It Go.” As she hears distant voices of the men searching for her, she now must decide what her next move will be. Even contemplating death, Elsa ultimately decides to stay alive and fix what she’s done.

True Love|Ft.\u00a0Patti\u00a0Murin.fact: In this song Anna talks about how all her life she had wished to find true love and she still hasn’t lost faith, but admits that before she didn’t know what true love was.

When Everything Falls Apart|Outtake Ft.\.fact: Removed from the show during its pre-Broadway run in Denver, Colorado, “When Everything Falls Apart” is Olaf’s song about what he does when things are not going exactly as planned.

Happy Working Song|by Amy\u00a0Adams.fact: Giselle (Amy Adams) finds herself alone in the apartment and uses her magical powers to summon the wildlife to help her clean up the place. Since this is New York, the main wildlife are cockroaches, rats, and pigeons, but they’re eager to help anyway. This song parodies a number of other songs from Disney animated films, especially “Whistle While You Work” from Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.

That's How You Know|by Amy\u00a0Adams.fact: One of three songs from the film nominated for an Academy Award for Best Song, Giselle (Amy Adams) sings this song expressing hope for Robert’s new relationship. Eventually, everyone in Central Park joins in her number, while Robert (Patrick Dempsey) is stunned that everyone seems to know this song that he’s never heard before – it’s a joke referring to the fact that background characters in musicals always seem to know how to join in with a song even if it’s their first time hearing it.

Ever Ever After|by Carrie\u00a0Underwood.fact: “Ever Ever After” is the song playing during the ending of Enchanted when the lives of the characters after the movie are shown. According to Alan Menken the songs in Enchanted were made to gradually go from stereotypical traditional Disney songs to more contemporary songs, so being the last song in the movie, it is the most modern song. It was also the last song to be composed for the film.

The Family Madrigal|by Stephanie\u00a0Be.fact: “The Family Madrigal” is the introduction song from Disney’s 2021 musical film Encanto. It introduces the key family members of the main character, Mirabel, as well as one of the key characteristics of the movie—each of Mirabel’s family members (except for the two men who married into the family) has some sort of magical power, but Mirabel does not.

Waiting On A Miracle|by Stephanie\u00a0B.fact: “Waiting on a Miracle” is the ‘I Want’ song for Mirabel. The musical style is the Colombian bambuco. It’s in ¾ meter, which is rare for a Disney song but also symbolizes the disconnect between Mirabel and the rest of her family. In the song, Mirabel laments how all of her family members have magical abilities, but she doesn’t – at first, she tries to pretend that she’s okay with being less special, but eventually she drops the act and decides instead to plead for another chance at getting a magical power of her own.

Surface Pressure|by Jessica\u00a0Darrow.fact: “Surface Pressure” is Luisa’s solo. Luisa is Mirabel’s sister, and her magical ability is that she has superhuman strength. However, as she says in this song, her strength still has its limits, as she has an emotional breakdown.

We Don't Talk About Bruno|by Carolina\u0.fact:
This Colombian Cha-Cha-style song includes the Madrigal Family warning Mirabel not to mention her uncle Bruno, who has the gift of telling prophecy. Since his sometimes troubling prophecies come true, he is the mysterious outcast of the family.

It’s also the first Disney song since “A Whole New World” to reach the first position on the Billboard hot 100, becoming Disney’s most recent hit.

What Else Can I Do?|by Diane\u00a0Guerre.fact: This song features Mirabel and her sister Isabela, whose magical power is summoning flowers and plants and overall being graceful (which leads her family members and the townsfolk to consider her “effortlessly perfect”). In the song, Isabela realizes that even though she’s been trying to be as perfect as she can, there are other ways she can use her powers to be creative and explore.

Dos Oruguitas|by Sebasti\u00e1n\u00a0Yat.fact: One of the few all-Spanish song in Encanto, “Dos Oruguitas” tells the story of two caterpillars growing to become butterflies and find their own future. In the movie, it represents the story of Mirabel’s grandparents. The English version, “Two Oruguitas”, is played in the end credits.

All Of You|by Stephanie\u00a0Beatriz, Ol.fact: The final song of Encanto brings back musical and literary themes presented through the film, tying them together to form the resolution at the end of this story’s arc. The family Madrigal is left with their home in rubble, and through this song find a way to overcome the tragedy and see themselves and each other in a new light.

\u00a1Hola Casita!|by Germaine\u00a0Fran.title: ¡Hola Casita!
\u00a1Hola Casita!|by Germaine\u00a0Fran.fact:
This song is used two times in Encanto:

1) at the very beginning, when Abuela Alma first receives a miracle and Casita starts forming around her, and

2) at the very end, when Mirabel places the doorknob in the newly-built man-made house for the Madrigals, the house begins to come to life.

Colombia, Mi Encanto|by Carlos\u00a0Vive.fact: Worldwide music figure Carlos Vives sings this love letter to Colombia played in the Encanto trailer and credits. Producer Lin-Manuel Miranda loves Carlos Vives' music and wanted to write the most joyous song possible inspired by Carlos Vives' writings in the Colombian folk music style, vallenato. Carlos Vives recorded the song with his own band and musicians.
